title: Will Canada announce a diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, China, before 1 February 2022?
preds: Raised significantly on BoJo saying there will be "effectively" a diplomatic boycott.
Australia and now the UK have announced bycotts.
Increasing my forecast due to Australia joining in the boycott and some gentle pressure from the US ambassador: https://globalnews.ca/news/8432421/beijing-olympics-boycott-ambassador/
Slight shift in position with Australia announcing a matching boycott
Canada will feel increasing pressure to boycott following announcements by the US and Australia.

The Group of Seven is composed of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK, and the USA. Of those countries, Canada has arguably the best record on Human Rights. Canada has never been the first of the G7 to take up any action but it seems imminent that Australia, New Zealand, as well as the UK, will all join the US boycott, giving Canada assurance needed to enter the boycott also.

Canada has a longstanding relationship with China which I am not sure if they will be willing to damage like this. 
Probability will increase the more other countries join like Australia - but- the UK is consistent in saying they don't boycott sporting events (repeated by Boris J in PMQT today) and I think Canada will probably follow a similar tack.
I believe they will announce close with the US to show a united front

The Chinese residential schools story will resonate with Canadians. The timing is non-trivial. Still thinking Trudeau will try to find a way to avoid a formal diplomatic boycott. 
https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-a-residential-school-system-in-china-is-stripping-tibetan-children-of/
If they do, it will be sooner than 2/1. The odds agains though are the large real estate investment China has in BC. Would really have a negative impact

Because this what the Biden administration has just done, and it seems logical that Canada will follow suit. There have also been recent diplomatic tensions between the two countries that seem to increase the odds. Finally, the world is souring on the CCP.
The US did, Canada will follow
Unlikely unless there is a western world cascade. To do so alone would make them look like America's lapdog and the whole western world to do so would create unnecessarily high tensions
ALL 3 OPPOSITION PARTIES ARE PRESSURING THE RULING LIBERALS TO BOYCOTT THE OLYMPICS IN SOME WAY

The Canadian government says it is actively looking at doing so. I think the US government will weigh in behind the scenes and encourage them to do so, while China will threaten and cajole them on the matter. I think ultimately they will follow the US lead, knowing Trudeau's showiness on issues of human rights and equality. It would probably take a much-heavier-handed approach by Beijing with aggressive threats of economic sanctions to compel their attendance. Indeed, such an approach may backfire and only convince Her Majesty's government in Canada that they cannot let China bribe and blackmail its way to acquiescence.

Starting at an admittedly rather timid 50% and will watch for more news out of the Canadian gov't. I largely agree with @Zauchka 's analysis, but put greater weight on the US having announced their boycott.  The current Prime Minister has in some ways mirrored the foreign policy opinions of the elder Trudeau, making him more likely to break with US policy. As Zauchka notes, Trudeau has repeatedly been soft on China relative to the US/5 Eyes over trade and Huawei, not to mention the fracas over joint military exercises . [1] On the other hand, factors in favour of Canada announcing a diplomatic boycott include:
- Canadian public opinion on China keeps falling [2] which could drive Trudeau to action (though it hasn't yet on the above items)
- US President Biden and Trudeau are more aligned politically, which may make Trudeau more amenable to following the US's lead on this (vs were Trump in power) [1] https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/secret-documents-reveal-liberals-dismay-at-cancelled-china-exercises
[2] https://angusreid.org/canada-china-huawei-meng-michaels-oct-2021/

It seems the Liberal administration will be the primary decider:
“Canada is considering a similar boycott, but Sports Minister Pascale St-Onge said moments after the U.S. announcement that the Liberal administration in Ottawa had not yet decided whether to mirror the American action…”
https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2021/12/06/china-warns-of-countermeasures-as-canada-considers-joining-us-diplomatic-boycott-of-olympics.html OTOH, the Liberals are a minority government propped up by the NDP. And—“NDP MP and foreign affairs critic … ‘If we did send a diplomatic mission, China is in fact choosing who gets to go on that mission…that in and of itself, to me, is problematic. But also I think there is huge problems having the Olympics in Beijing knowing that there’s genocide happening in that country,’ she said.”
https://beta.ctvnews.ca/national/politics/2021/12/6/1_5695400.html Happy to be proven wrong on this, but maintaining the initial forecast. The reason I don’t put much stock in the Liberal government on the issue is a history of problematic engagements with China.  - Chinese agents interfered in the latest election yet there was no official backlash. PMJT seemed happy to squeak out a win, no matter how small, no matter how it was achieved. https://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/election-2021/glavin-chinas-interference-in-canadas-election-doesnt-seem-to-faze-the-liberals/wcm/844c0d86-513a-4999-a90c-f67cc221c350/amp/
- Most recently: “In February, MPs voted to label China’s treatment of the Uyghur Muslims a genocide.” — But Trudeau’s entire cabinet abstained. 
- Canada remains the only member of the Five Eyes that has not committed to banning Huawei from its 5G network. That decision has been “coming soon” for two years now. (If you take Canada’s following suit in 1980 as a base rate, consider also this as a potential counterpoint.)
- Trudeau’s government was unable/unwilling to mount any meaningful response when the two Michaels were held hostage.
- Trudeau made concessions demanded by the Chinese government in the Canada-China Free Trade Agreement talks. https://canadians.org/analysis/trudeau-makes-concessions-secure-canada-china-free-trade-agreement
- There may be serious financial interests involved (there are some books on this) in handling China with what some describe as a “kid-gloved approach.” https://financialpost.com/diane-francis/diane-francis-trudeaus-inability-to-stand-against-china-is-a-stain-on-canada/wcm/e8d4dfa7-a2c1-45ce-8afa-9a771b9ac2ba/amp/

Initial forecast. Will have to look into the mechanism of announcing a diplomatic boycott in Canada. If it’s only or mostly up to Trudeau, not gonna happen. The resignation of Ottawa’s ineffective ambassador to China (much lauded by the Liberal leaders nevertheless) is interesting. https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/canadian-ambassador-to-china-dominic-barton-tenders-resignation-after-two-contentious-years/wcm/879a75e1-13cb-4111-95d6-bd7c9703de58/amp/

The opposition on both right and left are in favor and the government says it is considering it. The relationship with China is of course important to Canada but with such strong support for the move it is hard to imagine that they wouldn't do it.
https://globalnews.ca/news/8427924/beijing-winter-olympic-diplomatic-boycott-canada/
If I don't see other countries joining suit this year, I will come down a bit. There is also the possibility of any Ukraine conflict instigating a collateral boycott.
I'm guessing Canada will follow suit.

State of play:
https://www.politico.com/news/2021/12/06/ioc-diplomatic-boycott-beijing-olympics-523801 https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/feb/04/beijing-2022-180-human-rights-groups-call-for-winter-olympics-boycott
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jul/09/eu-votes-diplomats-boycott-china-winter-olympics-human-rights-abuses
https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/RC-9-2021-0385_EN.html (#20: "Calls on the Commission, the Council and the Member States to decline invitations for government representatives and diplomats to attend the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics unless the Chinese Government demonstrates a verifiable improvement in the human rights situation in Hong Kong, the Xinjiang Uyghur Region, Tibet, Inner Mongolia and elsewhere in China")
Canada is likely to follow the lead of the US.

In 1980, two weeks after Jimmy Carter threatened an Olympic Boycott if the USSR did not immediately withdraw from Afghanistan, Canada announced it would join a boycott.  Canada eventually joined the U.S.-led boycott.
